metadata.case_name: Petitioners (Sugar Factory Owners) v. State of Andhra Pradesh

facts.text: Petitioners own sugar factories as defined in s. 2(f) of the Andhra Pradesh Sugarcane (Regulation of Supply and Purchase) Act, 1961.
Agents of petitioners are occupiers of the factories as defined in s. 2(m).
Petitioners purchased cane from canegrowers within their respective factory zones.
State Government issued notifications levying tax under s. 21.
Petitioners have paid the tax on purchases for several years and further demands are being made.
Cane Commissioner empowered under s.15 to declare factory zone for supply of cane during crushing season.
Under s.16(1), occupier bound to purchase quantity of cane grown in zone and offered for sale as determined by Cane Commissioner.
s.16(2) prohibits canegrowers in factory zone from supplying or selling cane otherwise than per schedule.
Rule 20 requires canegrower to offer cane in Form No.2; occupier to enter agreement in Form No.3 or 4.
Agreement in Form No.3: occupier agrees to buy, canegrower to sell sugarcane at minimum price notified by Government.
Minimum price fixed under Sugarcane Control Order, 1966.
Ordinance No.1 of 1967 (replaced by Act No.4 of 1967) inserted s.21(1-A) levying tax on khandsari units up to Rs.3.50 per tonne.
s.2(kk) defines khandsari sugar; s.2(kkk) defines khandsari unit.
Sales and purchases of sugarcane exempt under Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1957.
Vacuum pan factories bought 32 lakh tonnes cane in 1965-66; khandsari units 2.70 lakh tonnes.
Petitioner in WP No.101 claims to be new factory eligible for exemption under s.21(3)(a).

legal_issues.text: Whether purchases of sugarcane by factories from canegrowers under statutory compulsion constitute 'purchases of goods' taxable under Entry 54, List II in light of Gannon Dunkerley.
Whether purchase tax can be levied with reference to tonnage/weight rather than price/turnover.
Whether s.21 impedes free trade, commerce and intercourse under Art.301.
Whether s.21 violates Art.14 by discriminating between vacuum pan factories, khandsari units, jaggery producers, and exemptions for new/expanding factories.
Whether s.21 is a use tax or tax on entry into factory premises.

petitioner_arguments.text: Purchases compelled by law are not under agreements of sale/purchase and not taxable under Entry 54 List II per Gannon Dunkerley as no free consent, no passing of property pursuant to agreement.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co. (1959 S.C.R. 379); Indian Sale of Goods Act s.4; Contract Act ss.13,14,15

petitioner_arguments.text: Purchase tax must be on price/turnover, not tonnage/weight.
Tax levied only on cane for use/consumption/sale in factory, not generally, hence invalid.
s.21 is use tax, not purchase tax.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: McLeod v. Dilworth; C. Naidu v. State of Madras; Diamond Sugar Mills v. State of U.P.
Firm A.T. Mehtab Majid v. State of Madras

petitioner_arguments.text: Discriminates under Art.14: vacuum pan vs open pan/khandsari/jaggery; exemptions arbitrary.

respondent_arguments.text: Occupier has option not to buy and freedom to bargain.
Differential treatment reasonable based on industry differences.

court_reasoning.text: Canegrower free to offer or not; if offers, occupier bound to accept on prescribed terms; results in valid contract with free consent despite statutory compulsion; not coercion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Compulsion of law does not vitiate consent; enforceable contract of sale under Sale of Goods Act s.4.

court_reasoning.text: Tax on weight/tonnage valid; not limited to turnover.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Legislature competent to levy by reference to weight.

court_reasoning.text: Taxable event is purchase, not use; not entry tax.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Amended after Diamond Sugar Mills to avoid entry tax invalidity.

court_reasoning.text: Non-discriminatory tax does not impede movement under Art.301.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No direct restriction on transport; applies equally.

court_reasoning.text: Reasonable classification: vacuum pan factories (large, established), khandsari (small, recent), jaggery (cottage); exemptions for new/expansion based on policy.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Rational relation to taxation object; delegation valid.

holdings.text: Purchases under the Act constitute taxable purchases of goods under Entry 54 List II.

precedents_cited.case_name: State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley Co.
precedents_cited.relevance: Definition of sale/purchase requires agreement and passing of property.

precedents_cited.case_name: Indian Steel Wire Products Ltd. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Sales under control order with reduced bargaining are taxable.

precedents_cited.case_name: Kirkness v. John Hudson Co. Ltd.
precedents_cited.relevance: Compulsory vesting without assent not sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: New India Sugar Mills Ltd. v. Commissioner of Sales Tax, Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Directions under control order without offer/acceptance not sale.

precedents_cited.case_name: Diamond Sugar Mills Ltd. v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents_cited.relevance: Cess on entry into factory premises invalid under Entry 52 List II.

precedents_cited.case_name: Atiabari Tea Co. Ltd. v. State of Assam
precedents_cited.relevance: Art.301 protects free movement; direct restrictions invalid.

precedents_cited.case_name: Automobile Transport (Rajasthan) Ltd. v. State of Rajasthan
Firm A.T. Mehtab Majid Co. v. State of Madras
precedents_cited.relevance: Discriminatory sales tax may violate Art.301/304.

statutes_cited.relevance: Levy of tax on purchase of cane by factories/khandsari units; regulation of supply and agreements.

statutes_cited.relevance: Form of agreements for cane supply.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Contract Act, 1872
statutes_cited.relevance: Free consent, coercion, agreements as contracts.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Taxing power on purchases; equality; free trade.

statutes_cited.name: Andhra Pradesh General Sales Tax Act, 1957

outcome.summary: Writ petitions challenging constitutionality and vires of s.21 held without merit; s.21 upheld as valid purchase tax; no mandamus or refund directed.

key_quotes.text: "The consent of the occupier of the factory to the agreement is not caused by coercion... His consent is free as defined in s.14 though obliged by law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core reasoning on validity of compelled contracts as sales.

key_quotes.text: "The differential treatment... is reasonable and has a rational relation to the object of the Act. There is thus no violation of Art.14."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A non-discriminatory tax on goods does not offend Art.301 unless it directly impedes the free movement."
key_quotes.speaker: court
